t: Job 39
“Do*pn you know the time when the wild mountain goats bear young? Or*ild can you mark when the deer gives birth?
Can*ld you number the months that*i they fulfill? Or*ld do you know the time when they bear young?
They*ld bow down, They*ld bring forth their young, They*ld deliver their offspring.
Their*ld young ones are healthy, They*ld grow strong with grain; They*ld depart and do not return to them.
“Who*ln set the wild donkey free? Who*ld loosed the bonds of the onager,
Whose*ld home I have made the wilderness, And*ld the barren land his dwelling?
He*ld scorns the tumult of the city; He*ld does not heed the shouts of the driver.
The*ld range of the mountains is*i his pasture, And*ld he searches after every green thing.
“Will*ln the wild ox be willing to serve you? Will*ld he bed by your manger?
Can*ld you bind the wild ox in the furrow with ropes? Or*ld will he plow the valleys behind you?
Will*ld you trust him because his strength is*i great? Or*ld will you leave your labor to him?
Will*ld you trust him to bring home your grain, And*ld gather it to your threshing floor?
“The*ln wings of the ostrich wave proudly, But*ld are her wings and pinions like*i the*i kindly stork’s?
For*ld she leaves her eggs on the ground, And*ld warms them in the dust;
She*ld forgets that a foot may crush them, Or*ld that a wild beast may break them.
She*ld treats her young harshly, as though they*i were*i not hers; Her*ld labor is in vain, without concern,
Because*ld God deprived her of wisdom, And*ld did not endow her with understanding.
When*ld she lifts herself on high, She*ld scorns the horse and its rider.
“Have*ln you given the horse strength? Have*ld you clothed his neck with thunder?
Can*ld you frighten him like a locust? His*ld majestic snorting strikes terror.
He*ld paws in the valley, and rejoices in his*i strength; He*ld gallops into the clash of arms.
He*ld mocks at fear, and is not frightened; Nor*ld does he turn back from the sword.
The*ld quiver rattles against him, The*ld glittering spear and javelin.
He*ld devours the distance with fierceness and rage; Nor*ld does he come to a halt because the trumpet has*i sounded.
At*ld the*i blast*i of*i the trumpet he says, ‘Aha!’ He*ld smells the battle from afar, The*ld thunder of captains and shouting.
“Does*ln the hawk fly by your wisdom, And*ild spread its wings toward the south?
Does*ld the eagle mount up at your command, And*ld make its nest on high?
On*ld the rock it dwells and resides, On*ld the crag of the rock and the stronghold.
From*ld there it spies out the prey; Its*ld eyes observe from afar.
Its*ld young ones suck up blood; And*ld where the slain are,*i there it is.”*i
